Award.AwardTitle: Pan-American Studies Institute (PASI): Magma-Tectonics in Latin America; Managua, Nicaragua, 2013.
Award.AbstractNarration:
A Pan-American Advanced Studies Institute (PASI) will be held in Managua, Nicaragua, in 2013. The organizing committee consists of the Principal Investigator, Dr. Peter La Femina (Pennsylvania State University), Dr. Angelica Muñoz (Instituto Nicaragüense de Estudios Territoriales, Nicaragua), Dr. John Stix (McGill University, Canada) and Dr. Freysteinn Sigmundsson (University of Iceland). The PASI will address fundamental issues related to magma-tectonic interactions, in order to improve understanding of volcano-magmatic systems and thus help mitigate associated hazards, risks, and vulnerabilities. In particular, the institute will address four key scientific aspects, which will allow the scientific community to improve the science in significant ways: (1) Magma-tectonic interactions; (2) Deep vs. shallow magma plumbing systems; (3) Eruption trigger mechanisms; and (4) New approaches, methods, and technologies for volcano monitoring.

Arc volcanism is an ongoing threat along the backbone of the Americas from the Alaskan Aleutians to near the southern tip of South America. The hazards highlight the significant risk to people living close by, to civil aviation in terms of volcanic ash, and also regionally in the case of particularly large eruptions. Volcanic systems are in close-proximity to subduction zone fault systems. As seen in the recent past, subduction zones can generate large magnitude earthquakes that could potentially trigger eruptions. In order to examine these issues in a meaningful and novel manner, this PASI will have sessions on three distinct yet clearly related and overlapping themes: (1) geophysical processes, (2) geochemical processes, and (3) integrated studies of magma-tectonic interactions. Using these three approaches in an interdisciplinary fashion will provide new and important insights into subsurface magma behavior before eruptions, inter-relationships and feedbacks between magmatic and tectonic processes, and the events that initiate periods of volcano restlessness, including eruptions.

This PASI will bring together scientists from across the Americas for training in the latest scientific advances and technologies in volcano monitoring and modeling of magmatic and tectonic processes. It will give advanced graduate students and post-doctoral researchers from the U.S. the opportunity to initiate collaborations with their Latin American counterparts, and will enable Latin American colleagues to promote a professional network of scientists from across the region. Furthermore, it will utilize data from the NSF MARGINS program and the COCONet initiative to investigate magmatic and tectonic systems across the Americas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We wrote an AGU EOS article about our PASI Workshop outcomes. Part of the text from this article are peresneted below.

 

The Pan-­?American Advanced Studies Institute (PASI) workshop Magma-­?Tectonic Interactions in the Americas was held in León, Nicaragua (http://coconet.unavco.org/meetings/pasi-nicaragua.html). This workshop brought together researchers, postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students from every country in the Americas with active volcanoes, and one participant from Iceland. Lecturers presented the latest geochemical and geophysical approaches to studying magma-­?tectonic interactions. Participants were introduced to the tectonics and volcanism of Nicaragua through a daylong field trip and given opportunities to collect and analyze their own data, including seismic, geodetic, and geochemical data at the Cerro Negro volcano.

The interdisciplinary nature of the workshop allowed participants to venture beyond their scientific comfort zones to learn about cutting-edge approaches and techniques in a hands-­?on environment. As a result, all participants were able to both appreciate and use integrated datasets.

Given the scientific and geographical diversity of the group, the meeting allowed for important advances and contributions to scientists’ understanding of magma-­? tectonic interactions. Throughout the workshop, participants presented posters to share their research and exchange ideas with the group. A series of open discussion sessions were held, culminating with breakout sessions at the end to make specific recommendations for future research directions and provide avenues for collaborative research. 

Among the recommendations, participants generally agreed that a new group of Latin American “Decade Volcanoes” should be identified for intensive, integrated studies. Since the likelihood of an eruption at the Cerro Negro volcano is high in the next 5–10 years, the group agreed that intensive, integrative studies and monitoring should begin immediately. Cerro Negro’s eruptive activity is coupled with local (i.e., east-­?west extension) and regional (i.e., forearc motion) tectonics, so a better understanding of the feedbacks between the volcano’s activity and tectonic setting is needed.

In addition, the workshop participants agreed that Central American volcano observatories should have linked databases. The 5 September 2012 M7.6 Costa Rica earthquake was followed by increased seismicity and unrest at several volcanoes throughout Central America. By contrast, the 27 August 2012 M7.4 El Salvador earthquake was not followed by significant activity. The participants realized this as an opportunity to carefully document the geophysical and geochemical signals of unrest following the 5 September event and test triggering models.

The group also noted that Central American volcanoes show little or no deformation. Yet studies of degassing indicate that growth of volcanoes by magmatic intrusions is an important process. How can scientists reconcile this apparent paradox? Investigating recharge into magmatic systems, including magma migration, and multi-­?level storage processes is paramount.

Finally, participants agreed that future training efforts should focus on higher education students, professors, and researchers, and that data from local and regional networks should be open, accessible and provided in near real-­?time.
